name: Aam
description: Mango

name: Agahan
description: The Hindu calendar month during November-December

name: Amrud
description: Guava

name: Arhar
description: A pulse known as toor or pigeon pea (Cajanus cajan); typically planted in monsoon and harvested in spring; used extensively in dishes such as dal

name: Ashad
description: The Hindu calendar month during June-July

name: Atta
description: Flour of any grain, usually refers to wheat flour

name: Baasi
description: Leftover food from the previous day; also used to denote food that has gone stale

name: Baisakh
description: The Hindu calendar month during April-May

name: Bathua
description: An uncultivated green that grows abundantly in winter in this region

name: Bel
description: A fruit (Aegle marmelos), also known as Bengal quince. The Bel tree grows naturally in South Asia and is considered holy. The fruit is consumed directly or made into juice etc.

name: Beljharra
description: Jujube; a small red fruit harvested from shrubs that grow in the wild, sour in taste

name: Ber
description: Jujube; a small red or green fruit that grows naturally in most parts of India, sweet or sour depending on the variety

name: Bhadon
description: The Hindu calendar month during August-September

name: Bhatvaas
description: Bhatmaas is used in another parts of India, especially in Madhya Pradesh, to refer to soyabean. However, in this region bhatvaas refers to kesari dal, a pulse that grew abundantly but was banned as it contains a neurotoxin. The ban has been challenged and lifted in some states, and methods to remove the toxins have been discovered.

name: Chakbandi
description: This refers to the process of land consolidation undertaken in a village in accordance with the Land Consolidation Act. It was developed to tackle the issue of land fragmentation

name: Chaith
description: The Hindu calendar month during March-April

name: Chana
description: Gram, a pulse that was grown widely as a winter crop and used in a variety of foods. There are many types of gram, including chhole (garbanzo beans)

name: Chane ka saag
description: The greens of the gram plant, which were harvested when tender for consumption

name: Chaugada
description: Hare

name: Chaumaas
description: Monsoon, also refers to the monsoon crop in this region

name: Chutney
description: A savoury paste eaten as an accompaniment, usually made with fruits (including tamarind), greens, oilseeds etc.

name: Dal
description: A dish made of cooked pulses, salt and spices; eaten with rice or roti

name: Dhevda
description: 50% interest charged on loans, for example when ₹10 was borrowed on dhevda, ₹15 had to be returned

name: Fagun
description: The Hindu calendar month during February-March

name: Gur
description: Jaggery, a sweetener made from sugarcane

name: Haivat
description: The winter months, especially late December to early February, which were times of hardship and deprivation

name: Holi parikrama
description: An approximately 200 km route, all or part of which is traversed by Hindu devotees in this region during Holi, the spring festival. Villagers along the route typically provide food and drink to the devotees

name: Jaith
description: The Hindu calendar month during May-June; also used to denote the summer crop

name: Jamun
description: A purple tangy fruit also called Java plum or black plum (Syzygium cumini), harvested in monsoon, native to South Asia

name: Jhaabar
description: Wetland; low-lying land that is waterlogged for part or all of the year

name: Jondhri
description: The regional name for jowar or sorghum, a cereal grain

name: Jowar
description: Sorghum, a cereal grain that grows in the monsoon here, and ground into flour for human consumption. The plant is commonly used for fodder.

name: Jungle jalebi
description: A tropical fruit also called Manila tamarind (Pithecellobium dulce), grows wild in many parts of India

name: Kakun
description: The local name for foxtail millet, a minor husked millet that grows in the monsoon, and was usually consumed as rice

name: Karaonda
description: A fruit that grows on a thorny perennial shrub, sour and eaten raw or in chutneys and pickles

name: Karthik
description: The Hindu calendar month during October-November

name: Kodo
description: The local name for kodo millet, a minor husked millet that grows in the monsoon, and was consumed as rice. An indigenous variety in this region grows in 90 days (compared to 120+ days in other parts of India)

name: Kharif
description: The monsoon agricultural season, from June to October

name: Kunwar
description: The Hindu calendar month during September-October

name: Mahua
description: The mahua tree is indigenous to India and is revered by many communities. Its flower is consumed or made into liquor, its fruits are eaten raw or cooked and its seeds are used to make edible oil

name: Magh
description: The Hindu calendar month during January-February

name: Mandua
description: The local name for finger millet (ragi), an unhusked millet which was made into flour and added to rotis

name: Mauthi
description: The local name for moth or moth bean, a quick growing pulse that is cultivated in monsoon

name: Med
description: The borders between fields, which were traditionally wide and raised

name: Moong
description: Green gram, a pulse cultivated and consumed throughout South Asia

name: Panna
description: Fruit juice, often made from grilled raw mango

name: Pasahi
description: A type of wild rice harvested from wetlands in the region, the rice is red or black in colour and consumed by marginalised communities living near these wetlands

name: Patta
description: Title for agricultural land

name: Poos
description: The Hindu calendar month during December-January

name: Rabi
description: The winter agricultural season, from November to April

name: Roti
description: Flat bread made from unleavened flour, usually wheat but also pearl millet, sorghum and various pulses

name: Saag
description: Edible raw or cooked greens

name: Saanwa
description: The local name for barnyard millet, a minor husked millet that grows in the monsoon, and was usually consumed as rice

name: Saavan
description: The Hindu calendar month during July-August

name: Sabji
description: A savoury dish made by cooking vegetables with spices, eaten with rice or roti, can be semi-solid or liquidy

name: Sakat
description: A festival in January-February, during which sesame is consumed

name: Semra ka chhaal
description: The bark of the semra tree, which was consumed during drought and famine

name: Sharbat
description: Juice, made from fruits and jaggery/sugar but could also include buttermilk

name: Sharifa
description: Custard apple, a sweet fruit that is harvested in late monsoon (September-October), the tree grows wild in many parts of South Asia

name: Sitaphal
description: Custard apple, a sweet fruit that is harvested in late monsoon (September-October), the tree grows wild in many parts of South Asia; sometimes sitaphal also refers to pumpkin

name: Til
description: Sesame, an oilseed that is grown primarily as a kharif crop in this region

name: Tinni
description: A type of wild rice harvested from wetlands in the region, the rice is red in colour and consumed by dominant caste Hindus as fasting food at certain times of the year

name: Zamindar
description: Landlords, historically small kings or powerful men who controlled large tracts of land, and later received full rights to these lands under the British. They were often exploitative of tenant farmers. After independence and land reforms, they lost some of their land, but are still among the largest landowners and politically dominant families
